title: Domain-Driven Design Examples
description: Collection of example inputs for the DDD methodology process

examples.title: E-Commerce Marketplace
examples.description: Complete DDD for an online marketplace with buyers, sellers, products, orders, and fulfillment

examples.title: Digital Banking Platform
examples.description: Strategic design only - subdomains, bounded contexts, and context mapping for banking

examples.title: Healthcare Appointment System
examples.description: Tactical design for appointment scheduling - entities, aggregates, repositories, events

examples.title: Blog Publishing Platform
examples.description: Full DDD for a simple blogging platform - demonstrates DDD for less complex domains
highlights: Good starting point for learning DDD

simple.description: Single core subdomain, 1-3 bounded contexts, clear boundaries
simple.recommendation: Good for learning DDD, may be overkill for trivial apps

moderate.description: 2-3 core subdomains, 3-6 bounded contexts, some integration complexity
moderate.recommendation: Sweet spot for DDD - enough complexity to benefit, not overwhelming

complex.description: Multiple core subdomains, 6+ bounded contexts, significant integration
complex.recommendation: DDD is essential - helps manage complexity and team coordination

strategic.description: Focus on problem space - subdomains, bounded contexts, context map
strategic.when: Early in project, defining architecture, multiple teams

tactical.description: Focus on solution space - entities, aggregates, repositories, events
tactical.when: Implementing specific bounded context, strategic design already complete

full.description: Complete DDD from strategic through implementation planning
full.when: Starting new project, major refactoring, comprehensive documentation needed
